Lesson Narrative

Previously, students were given quadratic expressions in vertex form and asked to visualize the location of the vertex and the direction of the opening of the graph representing each expression. In this lesson, they reason the other way around and think about what expressions would produce graphs with particular vertices. Students look more closely at how changing the \(h\) and the \(k\) in a quadratic expression of the form \(a(x−h)^2+k\) translates the graph, and recall that the coefficient \(a\) affects the direction of the opening of a parabola.

Students continue to reason abstractly with expressions and graphs, but in one of the activities they also reconnect abstract expressions and quantities to a context. They continue to consolidate the ideas, structure, and generalizations from the past few lessons and apply them in new ways.

Learning Goals (Teacher Facing)

Students will be able to:

  • Create a quadratic function by changing the vertex of an existing function given its equation, graph, and a description.
  • Describe informally (orally and in writing) the effect on the graph of a quadratic function when performing simple algebraic transformations.

Learning Targets (Student Facing)

  • Describe how changing a number in the vertex form of a quadratic function affects its graph.

Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills (TEKS)


TEKS

Explanation of Coverage

A7(A) graph quadratic functions on the coordinate plane and use the graph to identify key attributes, if possible, including \(x\)-intercept, \(y\)-intercept, zeros, maximum value, minimum values, vertex, and the equation of the axis of symmetry;

Partial coverage: Lesson provides content that covers part of this TEKS. The parts that are covered have been underlined.

A7(C) determine the effects on the graph of the parent function \(f(x) = x^2\) when \(f(x)\) is replaced by \(af(x)\), \(f(x) + d\), \(f(x - c)\), \(f(bx)\) for specific values of \(a\), \(b\), \(c\), and \(d\).

Full coverage: Lesson provides content that covers all parts of this TEKS.

Lesson Activities

Here are the instructional activities for the lesson:

  • 7.17.1: Quadratic Expressions in Different Forms
  • 7.17.2: Modify Expressions to Translate Graphs
    • 7.17.2: Self Check
    • 7.17.2: Additional Resources
  • 7.17.3: Changing the Parameters of a Quadratic Expression
    • 7.17.3: Self Check
    • 7.17.3: Additional Resources
  • 7.17.4: Transforming the Parent Function
  • 7.17.5: Equations of Graph Translations

Students will also complete a series of problems in 7.17.6: Practice.

Required Materials

  • Graphing technology

Required Preparation

Acquire devices that can run Desmos (recommended) or other graphing technology. It is ideal if each student has their own device.

Lesson Vocabulary

During this lesson, it is important to:

  • Familiarize students with the vocabulary words they will see throughout the lesson. Encourage students to look for these words and notice their use and meanings.
  • Encourage students to use key vocabulary words in “math talk” and their written and oral explanations.
  • Utilize a word wall. Sample cards are located here: Mathematics Vocabulary Word Wall Cards.

Vocabulary words that are emphasized in this lesson:

Previous Vocabulary

New Vocabulary
  • quadratic function
  • vertex
  • parabola
  • none
